Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Ice Core Studies Reconstructing Greenland Climate During the Eemian and Beyond
Award.AbstractNarration: The primary goal of this collaborative project between three institutions is to understand the extent and evolution of the Greenland Ice Sheet (GIS) during the Eemian period (roughly 130,000 to 115,000 years ago, the last major interglacial period in Earth's history) and the deglaciation immediately preceding it ("Termination 2"). The GIS is an important agent influencing sea level, and Arctic and global climate, on multiple timescales. Its dynamics need to be understood in the context of past climate changes, but there is little information available about the footprint, volume, and elevation of the GIS prior to the last ice age due to the absence of continuous ice core records prior to 123,000 years ago. During the Eemian, the GIS was perhaps half its present size, contributing on the order of 3 m to "excess" sea level rise. Characterizing the evolution of the GIS during glacial termination 2 and the Eemian would improve our understanding of its dynamics, and enhance our ability to make projections of sea level rise during the coming centuries. Older ice does exist at the bottoms of previously drilled ice cores, but the extraction of age and climate information from this older ice is hampered by the fact that it is stratigraphically disturbed and, in many cases, contaminated with soil or bedrock material. These investigators propose several novel methods to date this disturbed and/or "dirty" ice and to extract information on climate and ice sheet extent. The investigators will combine their new measurements and other available data to develop a more complete history of the GIS during termination 2 and the Eemian. They will work with ice sheet modelers to investigate the constraints that the Eemian data provide for the models and improve their predictive capability. These efforts have the potential to improve our ability to predict the contribution of the GIS to sea-level rise in the coming decades to centuries. Educational and outreach activities include the training of two graduate students, inclusion of this research in summer teacher enrichment programs, a lecture series for graduate students and postdocs, and communication of the results through the news media.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Global warming is causing melting of the Greenland and West Antarctic Ice Sheets, leading to sea level rise. We have studied the response of the Greenland Ice Sheet to natural global warming during the Eemian (the last interglacial, about 125,000 years ago). This interglacial was warmer than our present interglacial, and in some ways serves as an anolog of the coming greenhouse world.

We have advanced our knowledge of the history of the Greenland Ice Sheet by studying stratigraphically disturbed ice (icewhose ordering is perturbed by flow, such that deeper does not necessarily mean older). It has been known that there are Eemian samples in such ice, but it has not been previously dated. We dated this disturbed Eemian ice by measuring gas properties that change with time in the global atmosphere, and asking when the atmosphere had the properties that we measure. We also established a collaboration with a modeler studying the Greenland Ice Sheet. The product of these studies is a history of the Greenland Ice Sheet during the Eemian. This history shows that, at the Summit of the Greenland ice sheet, temperatures were much warmer, and the elevation much lower, during the Eemian. We have also shown that an ice sheet persisted in the mountains of southern Greenland during the Eemian. Our results thus show that there was an ice sheet on Greenland during the Eemian, but it was much smaller than today.

From independent studies, we know that sea level was about 7 m higher during the Eemian than today, a consequence of the combined melting of the Greenland and West Antarctic ice sheets. Several recent papers attributed most of this sea level rise to West Antarctica, with Greenland melting playing a small role. Our results support this picture nearer the beginning of the warmest part of the Eemian (125,000 years ago). However they suggest that Greenland contributed most (about 5 m) to sea level rise by 120,000 years ago. These results suggest that the Greenland Ice Sheet is more sensitive to warming that inferred in other recent studies.

Our studies also show that the oldest ice at Summit dates to about 1,000,000 years before present. Therefore we are left with the view that the Greenland Ice Sheet has persisted since at least this time, probably longer. Howerver, the ice sheet is also dynamic; it did not completely melt during the past million years, but it did change dramatically in size and these changes had a signficant global impact.
